description: 1570s, "to cut unevenly" (implied in haggler), frequentative of Middle English haggen (“to chop”), variant of hacken (“to hack”), equivalent to hack +‎ -le. Sense of "argue about price" first recorded c.1600, probably from notion of chopping away.

verbs.description: haggle (third-person singular simple present haggles, present participle haggling, simple past and past participle haggled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To argue for a better deal, especially over prices with a seller.
examples: I haggled for a better price because the original price was too high.

entries.meaning: To stick at small matters; to chaffer; to higgle.
examples: Royalty and science never haggled about the value of blood.
